posts.name: Micah Doberne-Schor
posts.cooked:
Hi CD , About a year ago our team experimented with using vex limit switches (we have plenty from our school’s engineering department). However sketchy, those trigger switches worked quite well on our offseason bot for detecting cubes, so well in fact, that we decided it would be a good idea to use vex bumper switches to detect the note in our pivoting intake this past 2024 season. However, those switches have caused nothing but problems for us. At our first qualifier, we had one bumper limit switch. It kinda worked but not well. We did have to replace it a few times as it broke a lot. Between our qualifiers, we thought that it would be a good idea to increase the number of bumper limit switches from 1 to 3 in the hope that a broken limit switch would not make intaking hard, and to be sure that the note would hit the vex bumper limit switch. This turned out to be a problematic solution. The vex limit switches did break (we expected them to) but when they broke, they often defaulted to the triggered position. TLDR: the intake thinks there is a note when there isn’t and thus won’t actually intake. I’m pretty sure we ended up quickly coding a manual override, but even so, our autos were often screwed for that second qualifier, and many close “winnable” matches we failed to win because of this problem. We switched to a different limit switch not from vex for the DCMP , which worked quite well. We now are investing in other systems like break beams and photoelectric sensors going forward, along with the better limit switches.

Other teams may have had more luck with these switches, but from our expierence, it would probably be a good idea to invest in the more expensive, but probably better option if your team can do so.

CD , what has your experience been?

posts.name: Bailey Coulter
posts.cooked: We have never had them work correctly, they break a lot. We won’t use them in the future.

posts.name: bobbysq
posts.cooked:
I personally wouldn’t use Vex anything:

[cw: sexual harassment] An Open Letter to VEX General Forum

As for limit switches specifically, I would definitely get switches more suited for FRC , or avoid physical switches altogether as you mentioned.

posts.name: Kian J Ross
posts.cooked: Theres a ton of cheaper yet better options on the market.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
We added a VEX bumper switch to our final rebuild of our 2023 robot, because we had it.  The switch was hit by a flexing piece of lexan between two members of our arm.  That bit of flex kept it safe in the limited runtime that version of the robot, though we didn’t run it in anger a lot.

Like others, I don’t expect to source more of them.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
We had/have 4 Vex EDR kits circa 2017 with lots of the hardware still. I’m assuming these are the same bumper switches you are talking about and I did not like them back then either.

Their intended use case is to attach them to a chassis on the outside and use it for collision detection. Vex EDR bots were pretty slow so they survived some hits, but when we tried them in FTC they snapped on the first wall. The plastic felt cheap and easy to get stuck.

https://www.vexrobotics.com/276-2159.html

As others have said besides the cheap quality of these sensors, there’s other reasons to find someone else

posts.name: David Allred
posts.cooked:
Those Vex switches aren’t meant to be smacked.

We used arcade buttons similar to these from AndyMark in 2019 to detect the cargo balls.   They held up well.   That ball was like a thin walled kickball so it was not tough on the switch. Black Button Board - AndyMark, Inc

Currently we are using Adafruit beam break sensors to detect game pieces.   You have to be careful with detector placement.   These can detect other lights. IR Break Beam Sensor with Premium Wire Header Ends - 5mm LEDs : ID 2168 : Adafruit Industries, Unique & fun DIY electronics and kits

David

link_counts.title: IR Break Beam Sensor with Premium Wire Header Ends - 5mm LEDs : ID 2168 : Adafruit Industries, Unique & fun DIY electronics and kits

posts.name: Kellan Rohde
posts.cooked: But there hex stock is so cheap

posts.name: Sean Lavery
posts.cooked:
bobbysq:

I personally wouldn’t use Vex anything:

BouncingBuilder:

(we have plenty from our school’s engineering department)

The OP, like quite a few teams or engineering programs, have these in stock already. They’re a common component for any team that’s either used VEX EDR in a classroom or ran a VRC team. Using what you have in your shop and has already been paid for isn’t supporting VEX or their various issues. Don’t feel any shame in using what you already own.

BouncingBuilder:

defaulted to the triggered position

This will happen with any digital input. The default state that the RIO returns is true, therefore, a failed device will show this.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.custom_user_title: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
four:

any digital input

FRC robots tend to use single input (2-wire) sensors for simplicity. They aren’t super common in industry, unless you have a really low impact failure mode if you lose it.

A typical method for failsafing a sensor is to use a 3-wire switch that has both a normally open and normally closed output. The outputs would be wired into two different DIO slots. Normally a single one is true and the other is false, and then when the switch is triggered they change places. A cut wire (both open) and shorted wire (both closed) condition can be inferred if the two DIO are not inverse of each other.

posts.name: Ryan Dognaux
posts.cooked:
Just as another data point - 5010 used the newer VEX v2 bumper sensor this past season to home our shooter pivot. We made 3D prints that housed them and made TPU pieces that would hit the bumper sensor itself. Worked out really well for us.
